channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Canada, Surprise Win for Justin Trudeau
item.description: Mr. Trudeau has unseated the Conservative prime minister, Stephen Harper, according to a projection Monday night by the Canadian Broadcasting Corp.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau of the Liberal Party at a campaign rally this month.

item.title: Justin Trudeau, Following in His Father’s Footsteps
item.description: While Mr. Trudeau is the product of two political families — his father was prime minister — he came late to politics late, after working as a snowboard instructor.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau sits with his family as he watches results at his election night headquarters in Montreal, Quebec.

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Oscar Pistorius Is Freed
item.description: Oscar Pistorius, the Olympic runner who fatally shot his girlfriend in 2013, was released from prison and placed under house arrest on Monday night.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Low Voter Turnout Reflects System by Design in Egypt
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has attempted to virtually eliminate policy debate or ideological competition in parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Stranded in Cold Rain, a Logjam of Migrants in the Balkans
item.description: The fears of public officials and humanitarian groups were realized on Monday, when thousands of asylum seekers backed up at border crossings.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants were stranded in Trnovec, Croatia, on the border with Slovenia on Monday. At least 1,000 people spent the night in the rain and cold after being denied entry by Slovenia.

item.title: Migrant Suffocations in Truck Near Hungary Reveal Tactics of Smugglers
item.description: The deaths of 71 migrants in a meat truck found in August focused attention on the brutal tactics of human smugglers and the desperation of so many migrants.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy watching the funerals in Austria last month of four family members found dead in a truck that was smuggling migrants.

item.title: Hong Kong Bookstores Display Beijing’s Clout
item.description: Books about the private lives and back-room deals of the Communist Party elite are hidden or unavailable at stores owned by the Chinese government, which controls about 70 percent of the market.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CRYSTAL TSE
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The 1908 book store, which specializes in banned Chinese language books, has seen business fall off substantially in part because mainland tour groups are told by their guides that they are not allowed to bring banned books and magazines home.

item.title: Killing of Eritrean Migrant Shakes Israeli Confidence Amid Surge of Violence
item.description: A graphic video of people kicking a mortally wounded man and hurling a chair and bench at his head has shaken Israelis’ confidence amid a surge in violent attacks by Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: An Eritrean man, Haptom Zerhom, who was mistaken for an attacker and then shot by a security guard and beaten by a mob, Sunday in Beersheba, Israel. He died Monday of his wounds.

item.title: New Role for General After Failure of Syria Rebel Plan
item.description: The Army general in charge of the Pentagon’s failed $500 million program to train and equip Syrian rebels is leaving his job in the next few weeks, but will likely be promoted, officials say.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. Michael K. Nagata will probably be promoted.

item.title: Iranian Lawmaker Accuses Jason Rezaian, Washington Post Reporter, of Sedition Plot
item.description: In a new accusation, the lawmaker sought to depict Mr. Rezaian as a nefarious spy who collaborated with those seeking to topple the Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Zoeann Murphy/The Washington Post, via Reuters

item.title: U.N. Report Did Not Endorse Legalization of Drugs, Agency Says
item.description: The United Nations Office for Drugs and Crime said Monday that a “misunderstanding” had led to the impression that it would advocate the legalization of all drugs for personal use.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Exiled Yemen Government Agrees to Peace Talks With Houthi Rebels
item.description: The Houthis had previously indicated their willingness to attend the talks, which could be held in the next few weeks in Geneva, diplomats said.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: U.S. and Iraqi Forces Take Offensive Against ISIS on Several Fronts
item.description: Iraqi forces and the American-led coalition are putting pressure on Islamic State fighters to force them into the open so they can be targeted by airstrikes, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Iraqi forces and the Shiite militias fighting alongside them drive north of Baiji after retaking an oil refinery from Islamic State militants.

item.title: U.S. Withholds $5 Million in Antidrug Aid to Mexico as Human Rights Rebuke
item.description: The $5 million is only a fraction of America’s overall aid to Mexico, but is intended to send a sharp message.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters marched early this year in Mexico's Guerrero State, where 43 students disappeared in a case that shook the country.

item.title: Recent Quiet in Ukraine Offers Hope for a Peaceful Resolution
item.description: The guns have been silent for six weeks now, no small matter in a region where 8,000 people have died and two million have been displaced over 18 months.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: Pro-Russian separatists parked a tank in Aleksandrovsk, near Luhansk, Ukraine, this month. Weapons are scheduled to be pulled back from rejiggered front lines, and separatist leaders agreed to postpone elections until early next year.

item.title: Britain Unveils Plans to Fight Extremism in Young Muslims
item.description: The strategy announced by Prime Minister David Cameron includes a range of measures, stoking a debate about how aggressively the government should confront extremist ideologies.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, second left, and Home Secretary Theresa May, right, met with students in Luton, England, on Monday, during a trip to announce a new government strategy for tackling extremism.

item.title: 15,000 Years Ago, Probably in Asia, the Dog Was Born
item.description: The DNA analysis of a large and diverse group of dogs led researchers to determine that the most recent common ancestors of today’s dogs lived in Central Asia.
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN
item.media:description: Farmers playing with their dog in China's Inner Mongolia. A study says Central Asia is the best candidate as the point of origin for the modern dog.

item.title: U.S. Will Clean Area in Spain Where Hydrogen Bombs Accidentally Fell
item.description: The agreement between the two countries follows years of wrangling, since the 1966 accident, over the cleanup of plutonium and contaminated soil around Palomares.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, and Foreign Minister José Manuel García-Margallo of Spain after signing an environmental cleanup deal in Madrid on Monday.

item.title: World Briefing: Bomb on Commuter Bus in Pakistan Kills at Least 10
item.description: The bomb was reportedly placed on the roof of a commuter bus in Quetta, the capital of Baluchistan Province, and set off by remote control.
item.dc:creator: IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: After a Month, Still No Word From Saudi Panel on Hajj Stampede
item.description: Saudi officials have not given a detailed explanation for last month’s stampede near Mecca, which is estimated to have killed more than 700 pilgrims, more than half from Iran.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Iranian officials praying after the body of a pilgrim killed in last month's stampede in Saudi Arabia arrived at an airport in Tehran this month.
